results.name: Concatenate successive run lengths of 0's in the binary expansion of n, each increased by 1.
comment: Any positive number written in binary has its first bit equal to 1. From there on we count the 0 bits up to the next 1 bit or the end of the number. Each count is increased by one because of the impossibility of representing leading 0's in this database.
The sequence is prefixed by a conventional a(0)=0, which represents an empty sum or concatenation.

The positive integer n written as a binary digit string of length m uniquely decomposes into substrings of '1' followed by a maximal run of '0's where the lengths of these substrings forms a composition of m. a(n) is the concatenation of the parts of the composition of m when written in decimal. See A066099 for the table of composition parts. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 20 2015
Suggested by Armands Strazds's sequence A258055.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..f(n)-1} T(n,k)*10^g(n,k) for n > 0 with a(0)=0 where f(n) = A000120(n), T(n,k) = T(floor(n/2),k - n mod 2) for k > 0 with T(n,0) = A001511(n), and g(n,k) = Sum_{j=0..k-1} (1 + floor(log_10(T(n,j)))). - _Mikhail Kurkov_, Nov 25 2019
example: n=2 is written "10" in binary, so following the initial digit '1', there is one (= 1) bit zero; this 1 becomes increased to yield a(2) = 2.

n=3 is written "11" in binary, so following the initial digit '1', there is no (= 0) bit zero; after the next digit '1', there follow again 0 bits '0'. These two 0 are increased to yield two 1's, whence a(3) = 11.
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 16 2015
